Detailed Description

Fit Poisson/gamma model to data. The data consists of a sequence of counts (i.e., a histogram), presumed to arise from a mixture of sources, say , , and events. The goal is to find the yield of each source, given sequences of counts that describe the ``shapes" of the sources. In other words, given a data histogram and histograms , one for each source , we want to find the yield of each. This class solves the problem using a Bayesian approach [1].

Model

  • Likelihood - The likelihood function is assumed to be given by

    where

    The unknown parameters and are the source ``strengths" and expected source counts, respectively.
  • Prior - The prior is factorized as follows and is assumed to be a product of gamma densities:

    where

  • Posterior - The posterior density of the source ``strengths" is given by

    where the marginal likelihood , that is, integrated with respect to the nuisance parameters , is given in Ref.[1].

The form of the prior follows from the assumption that each count is associated with a Poisson distribution and that the the magnitude of the count is such that the likelihood dominates the prior. When that assumption is not justified, a reasonable procedure is to use Jeffreys prior[2], which leads to the replacement of with . For most practical applications, however, this will not make much of a difference.

References
[1] P.C. Bhat, H.B. Prosper, and S.S. Snyder, Bayesian analysis of multisource data, Phys. Lett. B407:73-78, 1997, FERMILAB-PUB-96-397.
[2] L. Demortier, S. Jain, and H.B. Prosper, Reference priors for high energy physics, Phys. Rev. D82:034002, 2010, e-Print: arXiv:1002.1111.
